This is the SECOND step: after internal repentance, EXTERNAL reform! Fix what you broke. Change your behavior. Replace bad with good. If you were concealing truth, start living righteously! Tawbah alone isn't enough - you must also reform your life!
Adds third condition - the most specific one for concealers...

grammar.reason: Third condition - CLARIFY what you previously hid! Form II shows intensive clarification. The 'ū' = they did it.
grammar.practical: Form II 'bayyana' = to clarify thoroughly, to make clear, to explain. 'Bayyanū' = they clarified, they made clear. This is the THIRD and most important step for those who concealed knowledge: PUBLICLY CLARIFY what you hid! You concealed truth? Now REVEAL it! You hid verses about the Prophet ﷺ? Now PROCLAIM them! This is the specific remedy for the specific sin. Beautiful justice: you hid clear signs? Repent + reform + CLARIFY those signs! The three conditions are comprehensive: (1) inner change (tawbah), (2) outer change (iṣlāḥ), (3) specific repair (bayān). Do all three!

grammar.reason: 'Fa' shows the RESULT of fulfilling the three conditions. 'Ulā'ika' points to them: THOSE people (who did all three).
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = then/so (showing result). 'Ulā'ika' = those. Together: 'Then THOSE people...' This is the answer: if they do those three things, THEN what? The reward/response comes next. Allah is pointing to them: THESE people who repented, reformed, and clarified - watch what I do for them!

words.translation: I will accept repentance / I will turn (in mercy)

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (in future meaning)
grammar.reason: Allah's response - I will accept their tawbah! The 'a-' prefix shows first person (I). When Allah 'makes tawbah' on someone, it means He accepts their repentance and forgives them.
grammar.practical: From tawbah. 'Atūbu' = I turn (in mercy), I accept repentance. The 'a-' = I (first person singular). This is ALLAH speaking directly! 'I will accept their repentance!' When human makes tawbah TO Allah, Allah makes tawbah ON the human (accepts and forgives them). SubhanAllah - what mercy! After you repent, reform, and clarify, Allah Himself says: 'I accept your tawbah!' Direct promise from the Creator!
''Alayhim' = upon them, to them. Shows who receives Allah's acceptance - THEM! 'Atūbu 'alayhim' = I accept repentance upon them = I forgive them, I turn to them in mercy!
Introduces Allah's self-description - confirming His nature.

grammar.reason: Emphatic 'I' - Allah emphasizing He's about to describe Himself with two Names.
grammar.practical: 'Anā' = I (emphatic). Allah is emphasizing: 'I AM...' followed by two divine attributes. This isn't just 'I accept your tawbah' but 'I AM the One whose NATURE is to accept tawbah!' It's who He IS!

words.translation: the Accepter of Repentance / the Oft-Forgiving

grammar.reason: First Divine Name - He is At-Tawwāb, the One who CONSTANTLY, REPEATEDLY accepts repentance.
grammar.practical: 'At-Tawwāb' = the Oft-Returning (in mercy), the Acceptor of Repentance. The pattern 'fa''āl' (like 'tawwāb') shows EXTREME intensity and repetition! Not just 'tā'ib' (one who accepts), but 'TAWWĀB' - He accepts repentance AGAIN and AGAIN and AGAIN! No matter how many times you sin and repent, He keeps accepting! The 'al' makes it THE divine attribute. This is His NAME - it's who He IS! You sin? Repent! He's At-Tawwāb - His door is always open!

grammar.reason: Second Divine Name - He is Ar-Raḥīm, the Especially Merciful. Emphasizes His mercy toward those who repent.
grammar.practical: 'Ar-Raḥīm' = the Merciful, the Especially Merciful to believers. From raḥmah (mercy). The pattern 'fa'īl' shows intensity - INTENSE mercy! While 'Ar-Raḥmān' (Most Merciful) is His mercy to all creation, 'Ar-Raḥīm' is His SPECIAL mercy to believers, to those who repent, to His devoted servants! Beautiful ending: He's TAWWĀB (keeps accepting repentance) + RAḤĪM (shows special mercy). Both names of hope and comfort! The verse ends with pure mercy after starting with curse. The door of repentance is always open!
